monogr.title: The strangling and death of the Great Turke, and his two sonnes : VVith the strange preservation and deliverance of his Vncle Mustapha from perishing in prison, with hunger and thirst, the young emperour now three dayes before having so commanded. A wonderfull story, and the like never heard of in our moderne times, and yet all to manifest the glory and providence of God, in the preservation of Christendome in these troublesome times. Printed this fifteenth of Iuly

div.head: ❧ The Printer to the Reader.
div.p:
I Am very loath to trouble you with a Preface, yet at this time you must pardon me; for it is for Gods cause, to exemplifie his glory & providence, that hath put an hook in the nostrils of Leviathan, and kept him from devouring poore Christians, who yet are in Armes to devoure one another: that hath throwne a stone from Heaven to strike the golden Image to powder, which was stretching it selfe, to overlooke and overtopp the Provinces of Europe; that hath put an Axe to the great tree, and felld it at a blow, which was beginning to overspread the earth, and be a shaddow for the beasts of the field. What, all Christendome almost in Armes, and yet the Turke not to take the advantage, but to be pulld short by the hand of God, and throwne backward into a graue? Where are your dreaming Gazettes, and Coranto's now, that talkt of such formidable preparation, and so many hundred thousand in an Army? Where is the threatning of Poland, and terrifying the Cossacks with so many thousand Tartarians? Where is their comming into Hungary, to begin a new Warre there? What all husht and quiet? Why, then thine be the honour O God, and all power, and maiestie, and goodnesse be attributed vnto thee? For thou hast taken pitty vpon our afflictions, and wilt set vpright thine owne cause, when the children of Edom and inhabitants of Babylon, cry downe with the walls of Ierusalem, and insult with clapping
their hands, to see the enemies of the Gospell thriue in their outragiousnesse.

This then is all I would say vnto you by the way of Introduction, to giue God the prayse, that the great Turke is dead so opportunely, whereby there is hope, that Europe shall be preserved from their inuasion, and those affrightings. And the same God, that hath compassionated the generall distresses of Christendome, take pittie likewise on the particular passions of Princes, that they rage not in their revenges, nor runne too violently forward in their race of bloud and destruction; but admit of peace and pacification to the eternall memory of their vertues, and worthinesse.
